overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish an accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program under the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [6] The program is designed to allocate funds to the counties to provide grants to eligible homeowners or homebuyers to finance construction costs, development costs, and non-reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of an accessory dwelling unit and purchase deed restrictions on such property. [7] This version of the measure was amended to insert appropriate standards for grant awards and to clarify the exemption from conveyance taxes. [7] [7]
agency_impact: The Department of the Attorney General testified that the measure does not appear to contain legally sufficient standards for the award of such grants involving public money as required by the Hawaii State Constitution. [7] Accordingly, the measure was amended to insert appropriate standards for grant awards. [7] Your Committee notes that the Department of Taxation is requesting that the conveyance tax exemption take effect on January 1, 2026, to allow for form and instruction changes necessary to implement the proposed exemption. [7]
policy_impact: To address concerns from the Department of the Attorney General, this measure was amended by inserting appropriate standards for grant awards. [7] The bill now specifies minimum requirements for grant applicants, including compliance with anti-discrimination laws and indemnification of the State. [6] [6] The measure was also amended to clarify that the conveyance tax exemption applies to any document or instrument conveying real property with a county-owned deed restriction, including the document conveying the deed restriction itself. [6] [7]
revenue_sources: The corporation may allocate funds from the dwelling unit revolving fund for the program. [6] [6] The proceeds in the revolving fund shall be used for the administration and purchase of deed restrictions as part of the accessory dwelling unit financing and deed restriction program. [6] [6] If a property with a deed restriction is sold to a nonresident, the corporation shall be entitled to fifty per cent of appreciation at the time of sale, to be placed in the dwelling unit revolving fund. [6] [6]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The measure was amended to address testimony from the Department of the Attorney General that the bill did not contain legally sufficient standards for the award of grants involving public money. [7] [7] Appropriate standards for grant awards were subsequently inserted into the bill. [7] Additionally, the bill was amended to clarify the exemption from conveyance taxes. [7]
